supplierLayers.label: Prime asylum accommodation providers
supplierLayers.description: The national accommodation primes control regional delivery, subcontracting, and hotel procurement decisions.
questions: Which sites, operators, and subcontractors sit underneath them?
Where did hotel dependence stay high despite policy promises?

supplierLayers.label: Hotel operators and site managers
supplierLayers.description: These are the entities physically operating or managing a named site used for asylum accommodation or related temporary placement.
questions: Is the operator the same as the freeholder?
Was the site repurposed quickly or repeatedly?
Are multiple named sites linked to one operator group?

supplierLayers.label: Freeholders, landlords, and charged owners
supplierLayers.description: Ownership chains matter because the public-facing hotel brand is often not the economic beneficiary.
questions: Who ultimately owns the site or SPV?
Are there recent charges, restructurings, or dissolutions?
Do ownership links connect multiple asylum sites?

supplierLayers.label: Subcontractors and service vendors
supplierLayers.description: The supplier chain extends beyond accommodation primes and can expose hidden cost centres or repeat local contractors.
questions: Which service categories recur across places?
Which local vendors appear around asylum hotels or bridging accommodation?
Do contract descriptions hide route-specific work under generic labels?

supplierLayers.label: Public body response spend
supplierLayers.description: Councils and other public bodies may incur route-linked costs without publishing a neat asylum budget line.
questions: Which rows can be tied explicitly to asylum hotels or refugee-response work?
Which bodies are carrying response costs without national reimbursement clarity?
Where do local spend spikes cluster around named sites?

integrityTechniques.label: Beneficial ownership chain mapping
integrityTechniques.description: Link site operator, freeholder, PSCs, directors, and charges so the economic beneficiary is not hidden behind a hotel brand.
integrityTechniques.origin: AI DOGE integrity model adapted for asylum hotels

integrityTechniques.label: Company status, shell, and dormant signals
integrityTechniques.description: Flag dissolved, dormant, shell-like, or newly formed entities appearing in route-linked supplier chains.

integrityTechniques.label: Cross-body supplier matching
integrityTechniques.description: Track the same supplier, operator, or owner across Home Office, council, NHS, and wider public-body contexts.

integrityTechniques.label: Property-to-spend linking
integrityTechniques.description: Join named sites and addresses to supplier rows, facilities work, land records, and local property intelligence.

integrityTechniques.label: Threshold-splitting detection
integrityTechniques.description: Identify repeated sub-threshold awards or clustered spend that may avoid fuller procurement scrutiny.

integrityTechniques.label: Temporal clustering and sudden activation
integrityTechniques.description: Look for bursts of awards, site activation, or ownership changes around hotel opening or route-policy shocks.

integrityTechniques.label: Director overlap and network scoring
integrityTechniques.description: Use co-director, shared-address, and linked-company graphs to identify repeated groups around multiple sites or suppliers.
integrityTechniques.origin: AI DOGE network centrality and co-director analysis

integrityTechniques.label: Revolving-door and interest checks
integrityTechniques.description: Compare public decision-makers, registers of interest, company roles, and supplier relationships where route-linked decisions are material.

integrityTechniques.label: Price, volume, and repeat-pattern anomalies
integrityTechniques.description: Find unusually high per-head, per-room, per-night, or repeat local response costs compared with peer areas and prior periods.

integrityTechniques.label: Secrecy-gap tracking
integrityTechniques.description: Treat unnamed hotel use, withheld site lists, and opaque operator ownership as reportable system risks rather than background noise.

publishRules: Do not publish an owner or operator claim unless the site-to-entity match has strong documentary backing.
Do not treat generic council spend or procurement as asylum or refugee spend unless the row text, supplier, site, or source explicitly ties it to a route or scheme.
Publish risk signals with provenance and caveats, not as unsupported accusations.
Keep route-specific facts, local evidence, and context infrastructure visibly distinct on public pages.

workflowLayers.label: Lead intake
workflowLayers.detail: Track named hotels, operator leads, owner leads, FOIs, planning documents, parliamentary references, and local media references in a CRM-style workflow.

workflowLayers.label: Entity resolution
workflowLayers.detail: Resolve site name, postcode, operator, freeholder, company number, charges, directors, and linked entities before publication.

workflowLayers.label: Money linking
workflowLayers.detail: Join entities to national contracts, local procurement, spend rows, or service vendors with confidence scoring.

workflowLayers.label: Public output
workflowLayers.detail: Export only the documented entity links, risk signals, and place summaries that survive provenance checks.

priorityQuestions: Which hotel sites and owner groups recur across multiple authorities?
Where is contingency or hotel dependence high but public site visibility low?
Which subcontractors or local vendors cluster around named asylum hotels?
Where do ownership changes, charges, or company-status issues coincide with site use or contract growth?
Which councils appear to be carrying route-linked response costs that are visible in contracts or transactions but not cleanly labelled?
